study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate in reducing serum myoglobin levels and mitigating organ damage in patients with hypermyoglobinemia after cytoreductive surgery and hyperthermic intraperitoneal chemotherapy.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate treatment accelerated the reduction in serum myoglobin levels and lowered blood urea nitrogen levels compared to the control group, suggesting potential benefits in reducing organ damage risk. However, serum creatinine levels remained stable in both groups.
population_specificity: 60 patients with peritoneal carcinomatosis treated with CRS + HIPEC (study group) and 25 cancer patients treated with conventional extensive surgery without HIPEC (control group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, efficacy, and whitening effects of sodium bicarbonate-based dentifrices for tooth stain removal.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate-based dentifrices are effective and safe for tooth stain removal and whitening, often outperforming non-baking soda dentifrices with higher abrasivity. Clinical evidence supports their use as part of daily oral hygiene.
population_specificity: General population using dentifrices for oral hygiene (specific demographics not detailed).
effective_dosage: Not specified (low concentration of peroxides mentioned but not quantified).
study_duration: Not specified (implied long-term use as part of daily oral hygiene).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the plaque removal efficacy of dentifrices containing sodium bicarbonate (NaHCO3) to those without NaHCO3 in a single timed brushing clinical study.
results_summary: Dentifrices containing 67% or 45% NaHCO3 showed statistically significant greater plaque removal compared to those without NaHCO3. All dentifrices were generally well tolerated.
population_specificity: Adults with a mean Turesky modification of the Quigley-Hein Plaque Index (TPI) score of ≥ 2.00.
effective_dosage: 67% NaHCO3 plus 1425 ppm fluoride (F) as sodium fluoride (NaF); 45% NaHCO3 plus 1425 ppm F as NaF; 0% NaHCO3 plus silica and 1450 ppm F as NaF (Study 1); 67% NaHCO3 plus 1425 ppm F as NaF; 0% NaHCO3 plus silica and 1400 ppm F as amine F/stannous F; 0% NaHCO3 plus chlorhexidine/aluminum lactate and silica with 1360 ppm F as aluminum F (Study 2).
study_duration: Single timed brushing for one minute.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential benefits of baking soda-containing dentifrices in improving gingival health and dental biofilm control.
results_summary: Some clinical studies demonstrated that baking soda dentifrices reduced plaque and gingivitis, but longer follow-up trials are needed to confirm their impact on gingival health.
population_specificity: Healthy and compliant patients (human studies).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether periprocedural intravenous hydration with sodium bicarbonate and isotonic saline reduces contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in patients undergoing cardiac resynchronization therapy (CRT) implantation.
results_summary: The study found that hydration with sodium bicarbonate and isotonic saline significantly reduced CIN incidence (0% vs. 11% in controls) and showed a trend toward reducing adverse cardiovascular outcomes, though this was not statistically significant. CIN was associated with higher 12-month mortality.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing CRT device implantation.
effective_dosage: One-sixth molar sodium bicarbonate solution (exact volume/frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical practice of administering sodium bicarbonate to treat metabolic acidosis in neonates and assess its effectiveness and potential harm.
results_summary: The study found no evidence supporting the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate in treating metabolic acidosis in neonates and indicated that its use may be detrimental. The justification for its use is based on hearsay rather than scientific evidence.
population_specificity: Critically ill neonates with acute metabolic acidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety, tolerability, and efficacy of sodium bicarbonate mouth rinsing, alone or combined with propolis, in preventing oral mucositis in breast cancer patients receiving chemotherapy.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate mouth rinsing (control arm) showed a 16.7% incidence of oral mucositis > G1, while the combination with propolis reduced this incidence to 0%. The intervention was well-tolerated with no significant adverse effects reported for sodium bicarbonate.
population_specificity: Breast cancer patients receiving doxorubicin and cyclophosphamide chemotherapy.
effective_dosage: Not specified (only mentioned as mouth rinsing).
study_duration: Evaluated over 21 days per cycle, with follow-up for 6 months.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the ergogenic effects of oral sodium bicarbonate (BICA) on exhaustive intensive endurance running performance, comparing its impact on time to exhaustion and maximal performance metrics.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate significantly improved maximal running speed in graded exercise tests but did not enhance time to exhaustion in prolonged high-intensity running. It increased blood lactate levels and maintained pH within normal ranges, though gastrointestinal side effects were reported in 15 participants.
population_specificity: 18 trained runners (VO2peak: 61.2 ± 6.4 ml•min-1•kg-1).
effective_dosage: 0.3 g/kg diluted in 700 ml of water.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether prehospital administration of Sodium Bicarbonate (SB) improves survival and favorable neurological outcomes in adult non-traumatic out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) patients.
results_summary: The study found that SB administration was associated with worse survival rates (2.3% vs. 19.8%) and neurological outcomes (1.2% vs. 10.6%) compared to non-SB-treated patients. Propensity-matched and imputed cohort analyses consistently showed decreased odds of favorable outcomes with SB use.
population_specificity: Adult non-traumatic out-of-hospital cardiac arrest (OHCA) patients managed by paramedics.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of a paracervical block containing sodium bicarbonate and lidocaine in reducing pain during Laminaria insertion before second-trimester abortion.
results_summary: The paracervical block significantly reduced pain after Laminaria insertion (median pain scores 13 mm vs. 54 mm in the sham group) and increased overall patient satisfaction with pain control (median satisfaction scores 95 mm vs. 70 mm).
population_specificity: Women aged 14-23 6/7 weeks of gestation undergoing Laminaria insertion before second-trimester abortion.
effective_dosage: 2 mL sodium bicarbonate combined with 18 mL 1% lidocaine (single administration).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the safety and efficacy of intraosseous (IO) administration of sodium bicarbonate as an antidote in poisoning cases, comparing its bioavailability to intravenous (IV) administration.
results_summary: The study found that IO administration of sodium bicarbonate showed equivalent bioavailability to IV administration in animal experiments. Adverse effects, such as fat emboli, were reported but were conflicting due to heterogeneity in study methodologies.
population_specificity: Human case reports and animal experiments (rats and swine).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effects of sodium bicarbonate jet prophylaxis on blood pressure in normotensive and hypertensive subjects.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate jet prophylaxis significantly increased systolic and diastolic blood pressure immediately after treatment in both groups. While systolic blood pressure returned to baseline by 15 minutes, diastolic blood pressure took longer to normalize in hypertensive subjects (30 minutes) compared to normotensive subjects (15 minutes).
population_specificity: Normotensive subjects and subjects with pharmacologically controlled hypertension (20 each).
study_duration: Single session (measurements taken at T0, Ti, T15, T30).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the pathophysiology of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) and evaluate the evidence for prevention strategies, including the use of sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: The study found that the value of using sodium bicarbonate and other antioxidant compounds for CIN prevention remains controversial, warranting further clinical investigation.
population_specificity: Patients scheduled to receive iodinated contrast media (CM) during angiographic or other medical procedures.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the efficacy of oral hyperimmune bovine colostral IgG (bIgG) antibodies against ETEC challenge when administered with sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was used as a buffer for administering the investigational product, but its direct effects were not evaluated. The study found significant protection against ETEC-induced diarrhea with antiadhesin bIgG and positive control groups.
population_specificity: Adult volunteers
effective_dosage: Administered thrice daily for 7 days, 15 minutes after each meal (exact sodium bicarbonate dosage not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to discuss the role of sodium bicarbonate in the emergency management of non-traumatic rhabdomyolysis, focusing on its clinical application.
results_summary: The abstract suggests sodium bicarbonate may be used in the emergency management of rhabdomyolysis, alongside fluid infusion, but does not provide specific efficacy data or outcomes related to its use.
population_specificity: Patients with non-traumatic rhabdomyolysis in an emergency department setting.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether hydration with sodium bicarbonate, compared to isotonic sodium chloride, reduces the risk of contrast-associated acute kidney injury in critically ill patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the frequency of contrast-associated acute kidney injury, need for renal replacement therapy, ICU length of stay, or mortality between the sodium bicarbonate and saline groups, except for a higher urinary pH in the bicarbonate group.
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with stable renal function (n = 307) who received intravascular contrast media.
effective_dosage: 3 mL/kg during 1 hour before and 1 mL/kg/hr during 6 hours after contrast medium exposure.
study_duration: 7 hours total (1 hour pre-exposure and 6 hours post-exposure).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a human challenge model for Salmonella Paratyphi A infection using sodium bicarbonate pretreatment to assess vaccine efficacy.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate pretreatment facilitated oral challenge with S. Paratyphi A, resulting in a 60% attack rate at the higher dose, with notable subclinical bacteremia but minimal symptoms. The model was well-tolerated and suitable for vaccine assessment.
population_specificity: 40 participants divided into two dose groups (20 each).
effective_dosage: Not specified for sodium bicarbonate; S. Paratyphi A doses were 1-5 × 10³ CFU and 0.5-1 × 10³ CFU.
study_duration: Monitoring until day 14 postchallenge or until diagnostic criteria were met.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether combined sodium bicarbonate and ascorbic acid could prevent contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in patients with chronic kidney disease (CKD).
results_summary: The study found that combined sodium bicarbonate and ascorbic acid reduced the incidence of CIN following catheterization in CKD patients. The results suggest a protective effect of this combination therapy.
population_specificity: Patients with chronic kidney disease (baseline estimated glomerular filtration rate <60 mL/min/1.73 m²).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of a mixed solution containing sodium bicarbonate (with or without Pronase) on image clarity and procedural efficiency during endoscopic ultrasound (EUS) examinations of the stomach.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate solution, when combined with Pronase, resulted in clearer EUS images, shorter examination times, and reduced saline usage compared to sodium bicarbonate alone. No significant differences in patient demographics or adverse effects were reported between the groups.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing EUS examination of the stomach.
effective_dosage: 60 mL sodium bicarbonate solution (exact concentration not specified).
study_duration: Single administration prior to EUS examination.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate could enhance the anti-cancer efficacy of mTORC1 inhibitors by counteracting tumor acidity.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate increased mTORC1 activity in cancer cells and improved the anti-tumor effects of rapamycin, leading to increased tumor necrosis, apoptosis, and reduced proliferation compared to rapamycin alone.
population_specificity: Cancer cell lines and two different mouse tumor models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of a sodium bicarbonate and xylitol spray (Cariex) on improving salivary flow and oral symptoms in patients with Sjögren's syndrome.
results_summary: Salivary flow rate improved in all groups, but the difference was statistically significant only in those treated with Cariex. The study suggests a practical approach for improving gingival conditions and alleviating oral symptoms in Sjögren's syndrome patients.
population_specificity: 22 women and 2 men with Sjögren's syndrome.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the effectiveness of high-volume fluid resuscitation and sodium bicarbonate in preventing acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients with rhabdomyolysis.
results_summary: The study found that creatine kinase is not a specific or early predictor of AKI, but a McMahon score of at least 6 on admission was more sensitive and specific for identifying patients who may benefit from high-volume fluid resuscitation. Mortality was significantly higher in patients who developed AKI.
population_specificity: 232 adults with confirmed rhabdomyolysis (creatine kinase > 1000 U/l) admitted to a Neurosciences and Trauma Critical Care Unit.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to systematically review the literature on intravenous sodium bicarbonate's effectiveness in reducing intracranial pressure (ICP) in patients with neurologic illness.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate infusion significantly reduced ICP in all treated episodes (21 out of 31) without elevating serum partial pressure of carbon dioxide, and no significant complications were reported. The evidence supporting this effect is currently limited (Oxford level 4, GRADE D).
population_specificity: Patients with neurologic illness and elevated intracranial pressure (19 patients across studies).

study_goal: To compare pain during injection of plain versus alkalinised (with sodium bicarbonate) local anaesthetic solution for eye surgery.
results_summary: The alkalinised solution significantly reduced pain scores during injection compared to the control group, with a median pain score of 3 versus 6 (P=0.02). Buffering local anaesthetics with sodium bicarbonate improved patient comfort.
population_specificity: 40 consecutive patients undergoing eye surgery.
effective_dosage: 0.15mEq sodium bicarbonate per 10ml of anaesthetic solution.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether correcting metabolic acidosis with sodium bicarbonate reduces insulin resistance in diabetic type 2 chronic kidney disease patients.
results_summary: Treated patients showed better metabolic control, including lower insulin levels, reduced HOMA-IR scores, and decreased need for oral antidiabetic drugs. The largest reduction in insulin resistance occurred when serum bicarbonate levels were maintained between 24 and 28 mmol/L.
population_specificity: 145 chronic kidney disease patients with type 2 diabetes (83 men, 62 women) treated with oral antidiabetic drugs.
effective_dosage: Average dose of 0.7 ± 0.2 mmol/kg to achieve serum bicarbonate levels of 24-28 mmol/L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether 3% sodium bicarbonate saline solution could effectively prevent oral candidiasis in patients after free flap reconstruction surgery.
results_summary: The study found that using 3% sodium bicarbonate saline solution for oral care significantly reduced the incidence of oral candidiasis (2.0% vs. 13.0% in the control group) and maintained higher salivary pH levels from postoperative days 6 to 14.
population_specificity: Patients who underwent free flap surgery for oral and maxillofacial reconstruction.
effective_dosage: 3% sodium bicarbonate saline solution (frequency not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify effective treatment methods for exertional rhabdomyolysis in athletes, including the potential role of sodium bicarbonate in reducing CK levels and myoglobinuria.
results_summary: The study found that sodium bicarbonate, when combined with normal saline in IV fluid replacement, may help reduce CK levels and myoglobinuria in athletes with exertional rhabdomyolysis, though effectiveness could not be conclusively determined due to study variability.
population_specificity: Adult and adolescent athletes (15 years and older) diagnosed with exertional rhabdomyolysis.
effective_dosage: Not specified (varied between studies, combined with normal saline).
study_duration: Not specified (hospitalization time varied by severity).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the response of grafted parathyroid tissue during sodium bicarbonate-induced hypocalcemia in CKD patients who underwent total PTX with AT.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate infusion successfully induced hypocalcemia in CKD patients, but the grafted parathyroid tissue showed a blunted secretory response with no significant changes in iPTH levels. The effect was consistent but clinically limited.
population_specificity: CKD patients (11 clinically stable individuals, including those with successful kidney transplants, peritoneal dialysis, and hemodialysis) and 5 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative sodium bicarbonate administration prevents postoperative acute kidney injury (AKI) in high-risk patients undergoing off-pump coronary revascularization.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate did not reduce the incidence of AKI compared to the control group (21% vs. 26%, P=0.458). However, it was associated with a higher need for prolonged mechanical ventilation (20 vs. 6 patients, P=0.003).
population_specificity: High-risk patients (n=162) undergoing off-pump coronary revascularization with at least one AKI risk factor (e.g., age >70, diabetes, chronic renal disease, heart failure, or emergency/reoperation).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate (SB) in correcting non-thyroidal illness syndrome (NTIS) and delaying renal function deterioration in advanced chronic kidney disease (CKD) patients.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate significantly improved NTIS correction and reduced the risk of end-stage renal disease (ESRD) compared to placebo, with a notable delay in eGFR decline. The Kaplan-Meier and Cox regression analyses supported these findings with statistical significance.
population_specificity: Patients with CKD stages 3-4.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether buffered lignocaine (mixed with sodium bicarbonate) was superior to non-buffered lignocaine in relieving pain during cervical procedures.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief between buffered lignocaine with adrenaline and non-buffered lignocaine with adrenaline during cervical procedures (MD -8.00; 95% CI -17.57 to 1.57).
population_specificity: Women with cervical intraepithelial neoplasia (CIN) undergoing outpatient colposcopy treatments.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether sodium bicarbonate has a beneficiary effect in preventing perioperative acute kidney injury (AKI).
results_summary: The study found no definite data showing a beneficiary effect of sodium bicarbonate in preventing AKI. The abstract does not provide specific details on sodium bicarbonate's performance compared to other interventions.
population_specificity: Patients at risk of perioperative acute kidney injury (AKI).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy of Na/K citrate and sodium bicarbonate in reducing the frequency of contrast-induced nephropathy (CIN) in patients undergoing coronary angiography.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in preventing CIN between sodium bicarbonate and Na/K citrate. Both agents were equally effective, but sodium bicarbonate was associated with a greater decrease in serum potassium post-procedure.
population_specificity: 210 patients with renal dysfunction (eGFR ≤60 mL/min/1.73 m²) undergoing elective or emergency coronary angiography with/without PCI.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if buffering tumescent anaesthetic solution with sodium bicarbonate to physiological pH reduces perioperative and postoperative pain during endovenous thermal ablation.
results_summary: The buffered solution significantly reduced perioperative and early postoperative pain compared to the standard solution, with no differences in other clinical outcomes or complications. Both groups showed 100% technical success and similar improvements in quality of life.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing great saphenous vein endovenous laser ablation with phlebectomy.
effective_dosage: 10 ml of 8.4% sodium bicarbonate per 1 liter of tumescent anaesthetic solution.
study_duration: Patients were assessed at baseline and at 1, 6, and 12 weeks post-procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of brushing with 67% sodium bicarbonate toothpaste versus 0% sodium bicarbonate toothpaste on gingival health over 6 weeks.
results_summary: The 67% sodium bicarbonate toothpaste significantly reduced the number of bleeding sites, Modified Gingival Index, and Bleeding Index compared to the control group, though the reduction in volatile sulphur compounds was not statistically significant.
population_specificity: Adults (≥18 years) with mild-to-moderate gingivitis, ≥20 gradable teeth, and ≥20 bleeding sites.
effective_dosage: 67% sodium bicarbonate toothpaste, used twice daily.

study_goal: The researchers reviewed evidence for pharmacological treatments, including sodium bicarbonate, for cardiovascular toxicity from cocaine abuse.
results_summary: The abstract mentions sodium bicarbonate as one of the agents reviewed but provides no specific findings on its efficacy or safety.
population_specificity: Human subjects with cocaine-induced cardiovascular toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of Sodium Bicarbonate in managing hyperkalemia, particularly in patients with metabolic acidosis or intact kidney function.
results_summary: The study suggests that Sodium Bicarbonate may be useful in patients with metabolic acidosis or intact kidney function, though it is no longer recommended for acute hyperkalemia management.
population_specificity: Patients with hyperkalemia, particularly those with metabolic acidosis or intact kidney function.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sodium bicarbonate reduces pain and erythema from jellyfish stings and whether it induces nematocyst discharge.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate may reduce erythema after 30 minutes of treatment and, along with papain, may reduce erythema at 60 minutes. It did not induce nematocyst discharge.
population_specificity: 96 human subjects stung by Chrysaora chinensis jellyfish.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether intra-operative sodium bicarbonate infusion reduces the incidence or severity of acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients undergoing orthotopic liver transplantation.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate did not significantly reduce the incidence of post-operative AKI compared to sodium chloride (37% vs. 33%, p = 0.79). While it temporarily attenuated metabolic acidosis, this effect dissipated by 48 hours, and there were no differences in secondary outcomes like ICU stay or mortality.
population_specificity: Adult patients undergoing orthotopic liver transplantation.
effective_dosage: 0.5 mEq/kg/h for the first hour, then 0.15 mEq/kg/h until surgery completion.
study_duration: Duration of surgery (exact time not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the strength of evidence supporting sodium bicarbonate's efficacy in preventing contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CI-AKI) after coronary angiography (CAG) and/or percutaneous coronary intervention (PCI).
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate showed significant benefits in preventing CI-AKI and reducing changes in serum creatinine and eGFR, but no significant effects on dialysis requirement, mortality, or hospital stay length. The evidence is encouraging but requires further well-designed RCTs for definitive conclusions.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing CAG and/or PCI (3,537 patients across 16 RCTs).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to provide an overview of antidote use in poisoned patients, including Sodium Bicarbonate, focusing on mechanisms, benefits, and risks.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide specific findings about Sodium Bicarbonate's effects, only noting it as one of the few regularly used antidotes with decisions based on mechanistic understanding rather than randomized trial evidence.
population_specificity: Poisoned patients requiring clinical management.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the role of sodium bicarbonate in managing acidosis in patients with rhabdomyolysis.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was suggested as a treatment option for acidotic patients with rhabdomyolysis, alongside aggressive intravenous saline resuscitation, to help preserve renal function. The abstract does not provide specific efficacy data but implies its use in a clinical context.
population_specificity: Patients with rhabdomyolysis, particularly those with acidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of sodium bicarbonate as a surface treatment on luting CAD/CAM composite resin workpieces compared to other treatments.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate had almost no conditioning effect on the CAD/CAM composite resin and resulted in debonding after thermal stressing (0 MPa), unlike aluminum oxide, CoJet, and SilJet, which showed high microtensile values.
population_specificity: CAD/CAM composite resin workpieces (Lava Ultimate blocks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the severity, duration, and contributing factors of metabolic acidosis after deep hypothermic circulatory arrest (DHCA), indirectly assessing the potential impact of sodium bicarbonate administration.
results_summary: Metabolic acidosis was common and severe after DHCA, attributed to lactic and hyperchloremic acidosis. The severity correlated with maximum lactate and hospital length of stay but was not significantly influenced by DHCA duration or temperature.
population_specificity: Eighty-seven consecutive patients undergoing elective thoracic aortic surgery with DHCA at a university hospital.

study_goal: To compare the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate versus 0.9% saline solution in preventing contrast-induced acute kidney injury.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate did not reduce the risk of contrast-induced nephropathy, mortality, or the need for renal replacement therapy compared to 0.9% saline solution. No significant differences were found in any measured outcomes.
population_specificity: Patients with risk factors for contrast-induced nephropathy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a self-assembled stromal substitute could support endothelial cell functionality, including the expression of sodium/bicarbonate (Na(+)/HCO3-) cotransporter pumps.
results_summary: The study found that the engineered endothelium expressed sodium/bicarbonate cotransporter pumps, indicating functional markers for endothelial cell activity. The stromal substitute demonstrated cohesive collagenous matrix formation and supported endothelial interdigitations.
population_specificity: In vitro engineered corneal endothelial tissue (not human or animal subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine which factors (lactate clearance, vasopressor use, etc.) were most predictive of mortality in severe sepsis patients with lactic acidosis supplementing with sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: The study found that lactate clearance at discrete time points (6, 24, and 48 hours) and vasopressor use were significantly associated with mortality, suggesting these as more reliable prognostic indicators than initial lactate levels. Sodium bicarbonate supplementation did not show a clear survival benefit, with a high 7-day mortality rate (71.6%).
population_specificity: Critically ill patients with severe sepsis and lactic acidosis (n=109).
study_duration: Data collected over 3 years (May 2011–April 2014), but intervention duration per patient unclear.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate whether buffering lidocaine with sodium bicarbonate using a specific device (Onset) reduced pain during dental injections compared to standard unbuffered injections.
results_summary: The study found no statistically significant difference in pain scores between buffered and unbuffered injections for both inferior alveolar and long buccal nerve blocks, indicating sodium bicarbonate buffering did not significantly reduce pain.
population_specificity: Twenty patients receiving bilateral dental nerve block injections.
effective_dosage: 2% lidocaine with 1:100,000 epinephrine buffered 9:1 with 8.4% sodium bicarbonate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the consistency of metabolic and exercise responses following repeated administration of sodium bicarbonate (SB) and assess its impact on high-intensity cycling performance.
results_summary: SB consistently increased blood pH, bicarbonate, and base excess before exercise but did not significantly improve cycling performance in most trials, with only one trial showing a likely improvement. Individual responses varied, with some participants showing improvement in at least one trial while others showed none.
population_specificity: 15 physically active males (age 25±4 years, body mass 76.0±7.3 kg, height 1.77±0.05 m).
study_duration: Six cycling capacity tests (four SB trials, two placebo trials).

study_goal: To evaluate if a dilute sodium bicarbonate injection could confirm correct intravascular placement of a dysfunctional central venous catheter (CVC) in children at the bedside.
results_summary: All children with a partially dysfunctional CVC that was confirmed intravascular via venogram or thrombolytic therapy showed a distinct and predictable increase in end-tidal carbon dioxide after sodium bicarbonate injection. The method was found to be quick, simple, and effective for bedside confirmation.
population_specificity: 22 children undergoing chemotherapy with partial dysfunction of a CVC in a tertiary hematology-oncology care facility.
effective_dosage: 1 mL/kg (maximum 20 mL) of 4.2% dilute sodium bicarbonate.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the blood levels of omeprazole when administered as a suspension with sodium bicarbonate versus granules in pediatric patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in omeprazole blood concentrations between the suspension and granule forms, suggesting the suspension is a suitable alternative. The trough and peak levels were comparable between the two groups.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with acid peptic disorders.
effective_dosage: 2 mg/ml omeprazole in 8.4% sodium bicarbonate suspension.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of sodium bicarbonate (SB) and calcium in treating severe hyperkalaemia during cardiopulmonary resuscitation (CPR) and assess whether their effects correlated with serum potassium levels.
results_summary: SB administration was positively associated with sustained return of spontaneous circulation (ROSC) when serum potassium was <7.9 mEq/L, and combined SB/calcium showed a stronger association when potassium was <9.4 mEq/L. However, survival to hospital discharge remained low (3.7%).
population_specificity: Adult patients with in-hospital cardiac arrest and serum potassium >6.5 mEq/L during CPR (2006–2012).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the potential of sodium bicarbonate as a supplemental antidote for organophosphorus (OP) insecticide poisoning.
results_summary: The abstract mentions that sodium bicarbonate has been proposed and studied in small trials, but no definitive answers were produced regarding its effectiveness.
population_specificity: Patients with organophosphorus insecticide poisoning (no specific demographic details provided).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the pain relief efficacy of buffered versus nonbuffered 4% lidocaine (with sodium bicarbonate) during infiltration injections and incision/drainage procedures in symptomatic emergency patients.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in pain reduction between buffered and nonbuffered 4% lidocaine formulations during needle insertion, placement, solution deposition, or the incision/drainage procedure. Buffering with sodium bicarbonate did not enhance pain relief in this context.
population_specificity: Symptomatic emergency patients with facial swelling due to pulpal necrosis and associated periapical abscess.
effective_dosage: 0.18 mL of 8.4% sodium bicarbonate per buffered 4% lidocaine dose.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to review the literature on the electrophysiological mechanisms and clinical use of sodium bicarbonate as an antidote for tricyclic antidepressant poisoning and other toxin-induced sodium channel blockade.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate is effective in treating toxin-induced sodium channel blockade, particularly for tricyclic antidepressants, but its efficacy is uncertain for bupropion, propranolol, and taxine-containing plants. The mechanism may involve increased serum sodium concentration, alkalemia, or both.
population_specificity: Patients with poisoning from tricyclic antidepressants, citalopram, cocaine, flecainide, diphenhydramine, propoxyphene, and lamotrigine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose sodium bicarbonate infusion protects against contrast-induced acute kidney injury (CIAKI) and improves long-term kidney outcomes in patients with reduced kidney function undergoing angiography.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in the incidence of the primary composite outcome (mortality, dialysis, or sustained eGFR reduction) or CIAKI between the sodium bicarbonate and sodium chloride groups. CIAKI was associated with a higher incidence of sustained kidney function loss at 6 months, but bicarbonate did not mitigate this risk.
population_specificity: Patients with eGFR <45 ml/min per 1.73 m² undergoing elective coronary or peripheral angiography.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical and cost-effectiveness of oral sodium bicarbonate in older patients with chronic kidney disease and mild metabolic acidosis, focusing on physical function, quality of life, and vascular health.
results_summary: The abstract does not provide results, as the study is described as ongoing (BiCARB trial). The outcomes will assess physical performance, muscle strength, quality of life, renal function, and vascular health markers.
population_specificity: Older adults (aged 60+) with chronic kidney disease (GFR <30 mL/min/1.73 m²), not on dialysis, and serum bicarbonate <22 mmol/L.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative sodium bicarbonate infusion (POSBI) reduces acute kidney injury and improves post-operative outcomes in cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: POSBI resulted in fewer patients developing AKIN stage 1 renal failure but showed no significant differences in higher-stage renal failure, mortality, or hospitalization duration compared to sodium chloride.
population_specificity: 318 cardiac surgery patients (2008-2011).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether perioperative administration of sodium bicarbonate prevents cardiac surgery-associated acute kidney injury (CSA-AKI) based on randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences in CSA-AKI rates, in-hospital mortality, need for renal replacement therapy, ICU stay length, or ventilation duration between the sodium bicarbonate and control groups. Perioperative sodium bicarbonate did not reduce CSA-AKI incidence.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing cardiac surgery.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the clinical efficacy of a sodium bicarbonate-based herbal toothpaste against other toothpastes in controlling gingivitis and plaque over 6 months.
results_summary: The herbal/bicarbonate toothpaste showed no statistically significant differences in gingival and plaque index reductions compared to the fluoride-only toothpaste but was significantly less effective than the triclosan/copolymer/fluoride toothpaste.
population_specificity: 135 subjects in a single-center study.
effective_dosage: 1,400 ppm F as sodium fluoride in a sodium bicarbonate base, used twice daily for 1 minute.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of cerumenolytic solutions, including a mixture containing sodium bicarbonate, in dissolving earwax and reducing pain during removal.
results_summary: The study found that a mixture containing 10% sodium bicarbonate was among the most effective cerumenolytic solutions, significantly reducing pain and improving removal efficiency compared to other groups. The in vitro results also supported its efficacy in cerumen dissolution.
population_specificity: Pediatric patients with total or nearly total occlusive earwax plugs.
effective_dosage: 10cc of 10% sodium bicarbonate in a mixture with glycerine, hydrogen peroxide, and distilled water.
study_duration: Follow-up period of at least 10 days post-treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the use of sodium bicarbonate in treating severe lactic acidosis and shock caused by flufenoxuron poisoning.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was administered alongside crystalloid and dopamine, contributing to the patient's recovery from shock, though cardiac complications persisted temporarily. The abstract does not isolate sodium bicarbonate's specific effects from other treatments.
population_specificity: A 54-year-old male with flufenoxuron poisoning presenting with severe lactic acidosis and shock.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effect of monthly sodium bicarbonate with single or double doses of calcium gluconate injections on osteoarthritis (OA) of the knee, assessing efficacy and safety in the long term.
results_summary: Both sodium bicarbonate interventions (SBCG1 and SBCG2) significantly reduced pain and improved function in knee OA patients, with effects lasting 6 months post-treatment. SBCG2 also improved joint-space width more than SBCG1 at 3 and 18 months.
population_specificity: 74 knee osteoarthritis patients
effective_dosage: Monthly sodium bicarbonate with single (SBCG1) or double (SBCG2) doses of calcium gluconate injections
study_duration: 12 months of treatment, followed by 6 months of post-intervention follow-up

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether correcting acidosis in CKD patients with sodium bicarbonate affects inflammatory cytokine secretion.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate treatment increased serum bicarbonate and pH but decreased IL-10 secretion without significantly altering other cytokines or key clinical parameters like blood pressure and creatinine.
population_specificity: Thirteen patients with CKD stages 4-5 and acidosis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine under what circumstances sodium bicarbonate could prevent postoperative acute kidney injury (AKI) in patients undergoing cardiac surgery with cardio-pulmonary bypass (CPB).
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate significantly reduced AKI incidence (35.6% vs. 50%) in treated patients, particularly in low-risk patients (26% vs. 46%), but showed no significant effect in high-risk patients.
population_specificity: 342 patients undergoing CPB surgery at the University Hospital Goettingen, Germany.
study_duration: From anesthesia induction until 2 pm on the first postoperative day.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and gingival erosion effects of sodium bicarbonate air polishing (SBAP) against glycine powder air polishing (GPAP) and ultrasonic scaling in periodontal maintenance therapy.
results_summary: SBAP showed moderate to severe gingival erosion (scores 3 & 4) compared to GPAP (scores 1 & 2), with significant differences (P < 0.05). SBAP was less effective than GPAP and ultrasonic scaling in improving plaque and gingival index scores.
population_specificity: 22 chronic periodontitis patients with residual 5 mm probing depth in each quadrant.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of alkalinized lidocaine solution (containing sodium bicarbonate) versus lidocaine gel for intra-vesical anesthesia during botulinum toxin injections.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in pain relief between alkalinized lidocaine solution and lidocaine gel, with both showing similar efficacy. No adverse events were attributed to either treatment, but the alkalinized solution was nearly twice as expensive as the gel.
population_specificity: 54 patients of either sex undergoing intra-vesical botulinum toxin injections.
effective_dosage: 10 ml 8.4% sodium bicarbonate + 20 ml 2% lidocaine solution + 22 ml sterile Aquagel®.
study_duration: Single administration, with pain assessed at least 20 minutes after instillation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if Zegerid (omeprazole and sodium bicarbonate) provided faster heartburn relief compared to Losec (standard omeprazole) in GERD patients.
results_summary: No significant difference in median time to sustained heartburn relief was found between Zegerid and Losec, though Zegerid showed faster total relief within 30 minutes. Both treatments were equally effective and well-tolerated.
population_specificity: Patients with frequent (2-3 days/week) uncomplicated GERD.
effective_dosage: 20 mg Zegerid (omeprazole and sodium bicarbonate) or 20 mg Losec (omeprazole).
study_duration: Up to 3 days within a 14-day study period.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze the effects of air polishing devices, including those using sodium bicarbonate powder, on oral tissues such as cementum, dentine, and gingiva.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate powder caused significantly greater hard tissue modifications (defect depths and volume) compared to glycine powder. It also demonstrated higher potential for harm to gingiva compared to glycine powder or curettes.
population_specificity: Human cementum, dentine, and gingiva (ex vivo or in vitro settings).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to analyze patient perception, specifically pain and discomfort, during periodontal therapy using air polishing devices with different powders, including sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: The study found that air polishing with glycine or erythritol powders resulted in equal or lower discomfort compared to traditional root surface instrumentation, while sodium bicarbonate's performance was not highlighted as superior.
population_specificity: Patients undergoing non-surgical periodontal therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the alteration of human enamel when bleached with high concentrations of hydrogen peroxide combined with different activators, including sodium bicarbonate.
results_summary: The study found no significant differences among most bleaching treatments, including sodium bicarbonate, in altering enamel content. However, differences were noted in the organic matrix for some groups, suggesting sodium bicarbonate's effectiveness as an activator.
population_specificity: Human third molars (enamel/dentin blocks)
effective_dosage: 7% sodium bicarbonate (used in combination with 35% hydrogen peroxide)
study_duration: Three sessions with a 7-day interval between them

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether alkalinization of local anesthetic solution with sodium bicarbonate 1.4% reduces perioperative pain during Muller phlebectomies.
results_summary: Patients receiving sodium bicarbonate 1.4% with local anesthetics experienced significantly less pain during injection compared to the standard solution, though no differences were observed in peroperative/postoperative pain, complications, or other secondary outcomes.
population_specificity: 101 patients scheduled for ambulatory Muller phlebectomy.
effective_dosage: Sodium bicarbonate 1.4% mixed with lidocaine 1% and epinephrine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether administering a small volume of sodium bicarbonate intravenously could detect extravasation during infusion therapy by analyzing exhaled CO2.
results_summary: The study found that administering sodium bicarbonate IV led to rapid exhalation of excess CO2, which a pattern recognition algorithm could detect to confirm the absence of extravasation. Initial results from 89 oncology patients demonstrated the method's robustness.
population_specificity: Oncology patients receiving IV infusion therapy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether urinary alkalinization with sodium bicarbonate reduces the incidence of acute kidney injury (AKI) in cardiac surgery patients.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate did not significantly reduce the overall incidence of AKI but showed benefits in reducing severe AKI and the need for renal replacement therapy in elective coronary artery bypass patients. No differences were observed in the primary outcome between sodium bicarbonate and saline groups.
population_specificity: Cardiac surgery patients at risk of acute kidney injury (877 patients from three randomized controlled trials).
effective_dosage: 24-hour intravenous infusion (specific dosage not detailed in abstract).

study_goal: The researchers examined the effectiveness of sodium bicarbonate in treating diphenhydramine toxicity, particularly in a case of worsening symptoms despite treatment.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate treatment was ineffective in improving the patient's condition, which included recurrent seizures, hypotension, and wide complex tachycardia. Improvement was only observed after switching to intravenous lipid emulsion therapy.
population_specificity: 23-year-old male with severe diphenhydramine toxicity.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether sodium bicarbonate (BICA) improves prolonged, high-intensity cycling performance in well-trained athletes.
results_summary: BICA ingestion improved cycling time to exhaustion compared to placebo (49.5±11.5 min vs. 45.0±9.5 min) and increased pH, bicarbonate concentration, and blood lactate levels before, during, and after exercise. No differences were observed in maximal or sub-maximal performance measures during incremental tests.
population_specificity: 21 well-trained cyclists (age 24±8 y, BMI 21.3±1.7, VO2peak 67.3±9.8 ml·kg-1·min-1).
study_duration: Single-dose intervention with testing conducted 1 hour after ingestion.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of intravenous lipid emulsion in treating lamotrigine-induced cardiac toxicity when sodium bicarbonate treatment was refractory.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate was initially ineffective in resolving electrocardiographic changes from lamotrigine overdose, but intravenous lipid emulsion led to immediate resolution of these changes. The study suggests a potential role for lipid emulsion in cases refractory to sodium bicarbonate.
population_specificity: A 36-year-old male with bipolar disorder who ingested 13.5 g of lamotrigine.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore whether sodium bicarbonate, as part of an antiacidic approach, could target driver phenotypes in tumors to improve cancer therapy outcomes.
results_summary: The abstract suggests that sodium bicarbonate, alongside other buffers, may help control tumor growth, progression, and metastasis by targeting convergent cancer hallmarks, potentially enhancing existing therapies and reducing side effects. However, specific results on sodium bicarbonate's efficacy are not detailed.
population_specificity: Not specified (general cancer therapy context).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the clinical benefits and safety of sodium bicarbonate administration in various conditions, including metabolic acidosis and chronic kidney disease, while assessing its potential renoprotective effects.
results_summary: The study found no definitive evidence that sodium bicarbonate improves clinical outcomes or mortality in acute metabolic acidosis conditions, though it may attenuate kidney dysfunction progression in chronic kidney disease. Side effects include hypercapnia, hypokalemia, and QTc prolongation, with insufficient investigation into vascular calcification risks.
population_specificity: Patients with metabolic acidosis (e.g., diabetic ketoacidosis, lactic acidosis, septic shock), chronic kidney disease, and those on maintenance dialysis.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if sodium bicarbonate-buffered lidocaine reduced pain during breast lymphoscintigraphy and whether it affected lymph node visualization.
results_summary: Sodium bicarbonate-buffered lidocaine significantly reduced procedural pain without interfering with lymph node detection. No significant difference in lymph node visualization was found between the treated and control groups.
population_specificity: Female breast cancer patients undergoing breast lymphoscintigraphy.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the efficacy and safety of sodium bicarbonate versus sodium chloride in preventing contrast-induced nephropathy in patients with or at risk of renal dysfunction.
results_summary: The study found no significant difference in serum creatinine changes or contrast-induced nephropathy incidence between the sodium bicarbonate and saline groups, suggesting similar nephroprotective effects.
population_specificity: Inpatients with serum creatinine ≥1.2 mg/dL and/or type 2 diabetics scheduled for radiographic procedures with iohexol.
effective_dosage: 3 ml/kg of sodium bicarbonate solution (150 mEq/L) one hour pre-procedure, then 1 ml/kg/hour for 6 hours post-procedure.
study_duration: Intervention started 1 hour before and continued 6 hours after the procedure.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether administering a sodium bicarbonate and sodium citrate buffer with tOPV could improve vaccine immunogenicity by neutralizing stomach acidity.
results_summary: The buffer solution did not significantly increase immune responses to tOPV, though a marginal 7% improvement in response to poliovirus type 1 was observed (P=.065). No statistically significant differences were found for types 2 or 3.
population_specificity: Healthy infants aged 4-6 weeks in Sylhet, Bangladesh.
effective_dosage: Not specified (buffer solution administered with tOPV at 6, 10, and 14 weeks).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether high-dose taurine supplementation could improve mitochondrial function and suppress stroke-like episodes in MELAS syndrome.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation improved mitochondrial function in MELAS model cells and suppressed stroke-like episodes while enhancing taurine modification rates in leukocytes.
population_specificity: Patients with MELAS syndrome (mitochondrial myopathy, encephalopathy, lactic acidosis, and stroke-like episodes).
effective_dosage: High-dose (specific amount not stated in abstract)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine (TAU) supplementation, combined with metformin (MET), could enhance diabetes control and mitigate complications in a diabetic rat model.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation alongside MET improved metabolic parameters, restored islet mass, and exhibited antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and anti-apoptotic effects, reducing diabetes-associated abnormalities.
population_specificity: Streptozotocin-induced type 2 diabetic rats.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effect of taurine on skeletal muscle glycolysis in pigs, specifically through the HIF-1α signaling pathway.
results_summary: Taurine significantly reduced glycolysis-related enzyme activities and gene expression in pigs and porcine myotubes by inhibiting HIF-1α signaling, and it counteracted the glycolytic effects of the HIF-1α activator DMOG.
population_specificity: Finishing pigs and porcine myotubes (in vitro).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of taurine metabolic reprogramming in the development and progression of Abdominal Aortic Aneurysm (AAA) and identify potential biomarkers and therapeutic targets.
results_summary: The study linked taurine metabolism to extracellular matrix integrity and smooth muscle cell functionality in AAA, identified critical cellular alterations during AAA progression, and outlined gene expression patterns correlated with disease severity, suggesting taurine pathways as potential therapeutic targets.
population_specificity: Mouse model (GSE152583 dataset) and human AAA tissue samples.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine, in combination with chlorogenic acid, could improve wound healing and reduce acne scars by modulating inflammatory cytokines and promoting skin repair mechanisms.
results_summary: Taurine regulated IL8 and TIMP2 expression, accelerated keratinocyte proliferation, upregulated tight junction proteins, and modulated inflammatory cytokines (IL1α, IL1β, IL6) and skin hydration factors (HAS3). In vivo experiments showed reduced erythema, restored barrier function, and denser skin recovery compared to natural healing.
population_specificity: Human epidermal cells and irritated human skin (SLS-induced wounds).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of taurine and its transporter SLC6A6 in anti-tumor immunity and clinical outcomes in gastric cancer, exploring its potential as a biomarker and therapeutic target.
results_summary: Taurine exhibited a dual role, promoting tumor growth in immunodeficient mice but inhibiting it in immunocompetent mice by modulating CD8+ T cells. The study identified the SP1-SLC6A6 axis as a key mechanism behind chemotherapy-induced immune evasion.
population_specificity: Gastric cancer (GC) models, specifically immunodeficient and immunocompetent mice.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of taurine in lung cancer progression and its potential as a biomarker, as well as the suitability of taurine-containing drinks for lung cancer patients.
results_summary: Low doses of taurine and taurine-infused beverages promoted lung tumor growth, while higher doses showed reduced effects. The Nfe2l1-ROS-PD-1 axis was identified as a potential mechanism, with taurine's impact varying by immune competence and age.
population_specificity: 129 non-small cell lung cancer (NSCLC) patients and lung cancer mouse models (C57 and nude mice).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of taurine on MMP-9 levels and the expression changes of miRNA-21 and miRNA-146a in the SH-SY5Y cell line to assess its potential neuroprotective properties for Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Taurine showed no toxic effects on SH-SY5Y cells, increased miRNA-21 expression, decreased miRNA-146a expression, and significantly elevated MMP-9 levels at 1 mg/mL concentration. These findings suggest taurine may offer therapeutic benefits for Alzheimer's disease.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y cell line (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether taurine could delay intervertebral disc degeneration by activating mitophagy via the PINK1/Parkin pathway.
results_summary: Taurine treatment enhanced mitophagy, reduced oxidative stress, delayed cell senescence, and improved mitochondrial homeostasis in nucleus pulposus cells, slowing disc degeneration progression.
population_specificity: Nucleus pulposus cells (NPC) in vitro and in vivo models.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the causal link between taurine levels and immune cells related to skin aging using mendelian randomization, to explore taurine's anti-aging mechanisms via immune modulation.
results_summary: The study found a causal relationship between taurine levels and 10 immunocyte phenotypes, with taurine negatively associated with three and positively associated with seven phenotypes, suggesting its role in skin anti-aging through immune pathways. Sensitivity analyses confirmed the reliability of these findings.
population_specificity: Large European cohort

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine could protect human peripheral blood lymphocytes from radiation-induced apoptosis.
results_summary: Taurine reduced apoptosis in lymphocytes compared to the negative control group, with a more pronounced effect at 48 hours post-irradiation than at 72 hours. The protective effect slightly decreased with higher radiation doses.
population_specificity: Human peripheral blood lymphocytes (in vitro study).
effective_dosage: 100 µg/mL taurine, tested at radiation doses of 4, 8, and 12 Gy.
study_duration: Measurements taken at 48 and 72 hours post-irradiation.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to elucidate the regulatory mechanism of taurine biosynthesis in Trachinotus ovatus by studying the role of cysteine dioxygenase (CDO) and its promoter activity.
results_summary: The study identified the sequence features of ToCDO, demonstrated its catalytic activity in oxidizing cysteine, and revealed that HNF4α and NF-κB significantly influence CDO promoter activity, thereby potentially regulating taurine biosynthesis.
population_specificity: Marine fish (Trachinotus ovatus)
effective_dosage: 10.5 g/kg taurine in food (mentioned in a prior nutritional study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate whether taurine (Tau) alone or combined with enzymatically modified isoquercitrin (EMIQ) could protect against methotrexate (MTX)-induced cardiotoxicity in rats.
results_summary: Taurine protected against MTX-induced cardiac damage by improving heart conductivity and rhythmicity through antioxidative, anti-inflammatory, and antiapoptotic effects. Combined treatment with Tau and EMIQ offered superior protection compared to either agent alone.
population_specificity: Adult male rats
effective_dosage: 500 mg/kg of Tau, orally for 16 days

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the quantitative effects of taurine on hemodynamic parameters and cardiac function grading to assess its potential benefits for cardiovascular health.
results_summary: Taurine significantly reduced heart rate, systolic and diastolic blood pressure, and improved left ventricular ejection fraction and NYHA functional classification, with no significant adverse effects observed. The effects were dose-dependent and particularly beneficial for heart failure patients and healthy individuals.
population_specificity: 808 participants from 20 randomized controlled trials, including heart failure patients, hypertensive patients, healthy individuals, and those with other diseases.
effective_dosage: Not specified (meta-regression indicated dose-dependent effects but exact dosages were not detailed).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to characterize the structure of the taurine transporter (TauT) and identify key amino acids involved in ligand binding to aid in developing novel inhibitors for potential anticancer applications.
results_summary: The study used homology modeling, docking studies, and molecular dynamics simulations to identify critical amino acids (Glu406, Gly62, Tyr138) for ligand binding in TauT. These findings could facilitate the development of taurine transporter inhibitors as potential anticancer agents.
population_specificity: In silico (computational) study, no human or animal subjects.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine supplementation could reduce liver fat deposition induced by high-fat diets in orange-spotted groupers.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation (1%) improved weight gain, reduced feed conversion ratio, hepatosomatic index, and liver fat content in high-fat-fed fish. Proteomic and transcriptomic analyses identified key pathways (bile acid biosynthesis, glycerolipid metabolism) through which taurine exerted its fat-lowering effects.
population_specificity: Orange-spotted grouper (Epinephelus coioides)

study_goal: The researchers sought to determine how VacA toxin affects cellular taurine metabolism and whether taurine supplementation could protect against VacA-induced cell death.
results_summary: VacA intoxication reduced intracellular taurine and hypotaurine levels, and supplementation with taurine or hypotaurine protected cells against VacA-induced cell death. Taurine was the main metabolite significantly altered by supplementation, indicating its role in mitigating VacA toxicity.
population_specificity: Gastroduodenal cells (AGS and AZ-521 cell lines)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of taurine on hippocampal neurogenesis, neuronal preservation, and reversal of ethanol-induced damage in rats.
results_summary: Taurine treatment effectively protected against ethanol-induced deficits in the dentate gyrus, increasing cell proliferation (145.8%) and survival (54.0%). It also reversed ethanol-induced damage, increasing DCX-immunoreactive cells (41.3%), but did not induce neurogenesis in healthy rats.
population_specificity: Wistar rats exposed to forced ethanol consumption.
study_duration: 28 days (with two treatment protocols: during and after ethanol consumption).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess taurine's potential as a preventative and therapeutic intervention for Alzheimer's disease by reviewing studies from 2004 to 2022.
results_summary: The review found that taurine may protect against the onset and progression of Alzheimer's disease, with preclinical studies on murine models showing symptomatic improvement. However, clinical trials in humans are needed to confirm these findings.
population_specificity: Murine models (mice)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to assess the neuroprotective effects of taurine on SH-SY5Y cells by examining its impact on DHT, DHP, and the expression of miRNA-21 and miRNA-181.
results_summary: Taurine reduced LPS toxicity in SH-SY5Y cells, elevated DHT and DHP levels, decreased IL-1β and IL-6 expression, and increased miRNA-181 and miRNA-21 expression, with the most significant effects at 0.75 mg/mL.
population_specificity: SH-SY5Y cell line (in vitro study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether a taurine-modified hydrogel (GelMA-T) could improve neural stem cell viability and neuroprotection in treating ischemic stroke.
results_summary: GelMA-T demonstrated superior cytocompatibility, neuroprotective effects against ischemia/reperfusion injury, and enhanced neural stem cell proliferation compared to unmodified GelMA in both 2D and 3D cultures.
population_specificity: In vitro studies using SH-SY5Y and NE-4C cell lines, with potential implications for ischemic stroke treatment.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to summarize the role of Taurine upregulated gene 1 (TUG1) in liver diseases and explore its potential as a therapeutic target.
results_summary: The study found that aberrant expression or function of TUG1 is linked to liver diseases, and interventions targeting TUG1 or its pathways may offer therapeutic benefits for conditions like liver fibrosis, fatty liver, cirrhosis, and liver cancer.
population_specificity: Human liver diseases (e.g., fibrosis, fatty liver, cirrhosis, hepatitis, liver cancer).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the association between plasma taurine levels and self-reported symptoms/adverse clinical outcomes in patients with post-COVID condition (PCC).
results_summary: Higher plasma taurine levels were negatively associated with PCC symptoms and correlated with reduced inflammation, improved tryptophan metabolism, and gut dysbiosis. Increased taurine levels during convalescence were linked to significant protection from adverse clinical events (hazard ratio 0.13).
population_specificity: 117 individuals with acute COVID-19, followed during convalescence six months post-infection, compared to 28 healthy controls.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the mechanism of taurine's effect on hippocampal neurogenesis and its potential to improve autism-like behaviors in BTBR mice, a model for autism spectrum disorder (ASD).
results_summary: Taurine improved autism-like behaviors, increased hippocampal cell proliferation, promoted PTEN expression, and reduced mTOR and AKT phosphorylation in BTBR mice. These effects suggest taurine may enhance neural precursor cell proliferation and modulate the PTEN-associated pathway in hippocampal tissue.
population_specificity: Genetically inbred BTBR T+ tf/J (BTBR) mice, a proposed model of ASD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the role of taurine in ulcerative colitis (UC) progression and its potential therapeutic effects on intestinal barrier integrity and inflammation.
results_summary: Taurine deficiency worsened UC symptoms and intestinal barrier dysfunction, while taurine pretreatment improved barrier function, reduced inflammation, and inhibited the TLR4/NF-κB pathway.
population_specificity: Taurine-deficient mouse models (CSAD-/- and TauT-/- mice) and LPS-stimulated Caco-2 cells.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effects of taurine supplementation on metabolic syndrome-related parameters through a meta-analysis of randomized controlled trials.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation significantly reduced systolic and diastolic blood pressure, fasting blood glucose, and triglycerides, but did not significantly affect HDL cholesterol. No significant adverse effects were observed.
population_specificity: 1024 participants from 25 randomized controlled trials, likely individuals with or at risk of metabolic syndrome (specific demographics not detailed in the abstract).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine administration could improve outcomes in a mouse model of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH), particularly focusing on sensorimotor function, neuron damage, apoptosis, and astrocyte polarization.
results_summary: Taurine administration improved sensorimotor function, reduced neuron damage and apoptosis, and promoted neuroprotective astrocyte polarization while inhibiting neurotoxic polarization in SAH mice.
population_specificity: Mouse model of subarachnoid hemorrhage (SAH)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate outbreaks of A. marginale infection in cattle, including taurine breeds, assessing causes, treatments, and genetic diversity.
results_summary: The study identified tick infestation, needle/syringe sharing, and stress as possible outbreak triggers, with varying mortality rates (4.8-20%) and bacteremia levels (0-21.3%). Control measures, including discontinuing needle sharing and monitoring, were effective.
population_specificity: Taurine, zebu, and crossbred cattle in Brazil, including Holstein, Nellore, and crossbreeds, across different age groups and rearing systems.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to develop a biocompatible carbon nanofiber/taurine catalyst for synthesizing coumarins and 1,2,4,5-tetra-substituted imidazoles via a metal-free, cost-effective route.
results_summary: The study demonstrated that the carbon nanofiber/taurine catalyst was effective for synthesizing coumarins and imidazoles, showing high activity, excellent efficiency, and reusability. The catalyst's structure and acidity were successfully characterized using multiple analytical techniques.
population_specificity: Not specified (in vitro/catalytic study)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate taurine's therapeutic potential in countering steroid-induced muscle atrophy using a 3D skeletal muscle model.
results_summary: Taurine upregulated phosphorylated AKT, counteracted the hyperactivation of the ubiquitin-proteasomal pathway, and enhanced contractile strength and protein turnover via the AKT-mTOR axis when administered with corticosteroids.
population_specificity: In vitro 3D skeletal muscle model (not human subjects).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the effects of dietary taurine supplementation on performance, blood hematology, oxidative stress, and jejunum morphology in broilers.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation improved body weight gain, feed consumption, and feed conversion ratio, reduced oxidative stress, and enhanced jejunum morphology, with the highest dose (6 g/kg) showing the best results.
population_specificity: Broilers (Ras 308, 1 day of age)
effective_dosage: 1, 3, and 6 g/kg taurine amino acid added to the basic diet

study_goal: The researchers aimed to explore the effect of taurine on activated hepatic stellate cell (aHSC) proliferation and the mechanisms involved, particularly focusing on autophagy inhibition and ferroptosis induction.
results_summary: Taurine promoted the death of aHSCs, reduced extracellular matrix deposition, alleviated autophagy, and triggered ferroptosis and ferritinophagy, characterized by iron overload, ROS accumulation, and glutathione depletion. Bioinformatics analysis indicated taurine's direct targeting effect on nuclear receptor coactivator 4.
population_specificity: Human hepatic stellate cells (LX-2) in vitro.
effective_dosage: 10 mmol/L, 50 mmol/L, and 100 mmol/L taurine with PDGF-BB (20 ng/mL).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether the sex-dependent effects of short-term taurine treatment in hereditary cardiomyopathy were due to disease progression differences and to evaluate the efficacy of long-term taurine therapy.
results_summary: Long-term taurine treatment significantly prevented cardiac hypertrophy and early death in both male and female hamsters with hereditary cardiomyopathy, with varying degrees of statistical significance. The study concluded that the previously observed sex dependency was due to differences in disease progression rather than inherent sex differences.
population_specificity: 230-day-old male and female hamsters with hereditary cardiomyopathy.
effective_dosage: 250 mg/kg/day (low and high concentrations, exact high dose not specified).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate taurine's lipid-lowering effects and its mechanism of action on lipid metabolism in high-fat diet-fed mice.
results_summary: Taurine reduced weight gain, improved serum lipid parameters, increased SIRT1 activity and NAD+ levels, suppressed lipogenic genes, enhanced β-oxidation and lipolytic genes, and mitigated hepatic inflammation.
population_specificity: High-fat diet-fed C57BL6 mice (n=6 per group).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine if taurine and folic acid supplementation could mitigate the adverse effects of heat stress on lambs' growth performance, physiological indices, antioxidative capacity, immunity, rumen fermentation, and microbiota.
results_summary: Taurine and folic acid supplementation improved growth performance, physiological indices, antioxidative capacity, and immune status in heat-stressed lambs, while also positively influencing rumen microbiota composition.
population_specificity: Dorper × Hu crossbred lambs (27.51 ± 0.96 kg)

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine could alleviate liver injury in type 2 diabetic rats by improving antioxidant capacity and reducing inflammation.
results_summary: Taurine significantly reduced hepatic transaminase levels, improved liver histopathology, increased antioxidant markers (SOD, CAT, GSH-Px, T-AOC), and reduced inflammatory signaling pathways (JAK2-STAT1, TLR4/NF-κB, NLRP3).
population_specificity: Type 2 diabetic rats induced by high-fat diet and streptozotocin (STZ).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine could reduce microglia over-activation and decrease the accumulation of phospho-tau and Aβ in a mouse model of Alzheimer's disease.
results_summary: Taurine treatment increased taurine and TAUT levels, reduced activated microglia, decreased phospho-tau and Aβ deposits, and upregulated TREM2 expression in the hippocampus and cortex of SAMP8 mice.
population_specificity: Senescence-accelerated mouse prone 8 (SAMP8) mice, a model for Alzheimer's disease.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine prevents Angiotensin II-induced hypertrophy in human endocardial endothelial cells (hEECs).
results_summary: Angiotensin II increased hEEC volume and nucleus size, but pretreatment with taurine prevented these morphological changes and reduced intracellular calcium and ROS levels. Taurine effectively counteracted Ang II-induced remodeling in hEECs.
population_specificity: Human endocardial endothelial cells (hEECs) in vitro.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the efficacy of fluralaner for controlling Rhipicephalus microplus ticks on taurine cattle and assess its impact on weight gain and myiasis occurrence.
results_summary: Fluralaner showed near-complete efficacy (99.5–100%) in controlling ticks, prevented myiasis, and resulted in significantly higher weight gain (32.8 kg more) compared to the control group.
population_specificity: Taurine cattle in Rio Grande do Sul, Brazil, raised for beef and milk.
effective_dosage: 2.5 mg/kg pour-on, administered on Days 0, 42, and 84.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to identify changes in taurine levels in key brain regions (cortex, nucleus accumbens, and dorsolateral striatum) following amphetamine administration and abstinence.
results_summary: The study found increased taurine levels in the dorsolateral striatum (CPu-L) 28 days after the last amphetamine dose, suggesting long-term neuromodulatory changes. No significant changes were observed at 14 days, indicating delayed effects.
population_specificity: Rats administered amphetamine.
effective_dosage: Not specified for taurine (only amphetamine dosage: 1.5 mg/kg, 12 doses).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the effects of Taurine and Sucrose in individual sperm cryopreservation, assessing sperm motility, viability, and DNA fragmentation after thawing at different temperatures.
results_summary: Taurine combined with sucrose (S+T) showed comparable preservation effects to the commercial cryoprotectant (CPA), but CPA with thawing at 42°C significantly improved sperm motility. Other parameters did not differ between groups.
population_specificity: Normospermic semen samples from 17 individuals.

study_goal: To investigate taurine's effects on intestinal inflammation, gut bacteria, and liver/intestinal damage in rats with high-fat diet-induced NAFLD.
results_summary: Taurine reduced IL-17, increased IL-10, improved gut bacteria (higher Lactobacillus and Bifidobacteria), and alleviated liver/intestinal damage in NAFLD rats.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats with high-fat diet-induced NAFLD.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine the optimal timing and frequency of acaricide treatments for tick control in adult taurine cattle in a tropical region.
results_summary: Initiating tick control in early spring (T02) required fewer acaricide treatments (9 vs. 11) and resulted in lower tick burdens compared to starting in autumn (T01). This approach was more effective for managing ticks and reducing resistance issues.
population_specificity: Adult taurine cattle (Bos taurus taurus) in a tropical region.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to compare the potency and efficacy of taurine and homotaurine (HT) as GABA mimetics on native GABAARs and explore their potential therapeutic roles in dementia and autoimmune conditions.
results_summary: The study found that HT is a potent GABA mimetic with higher potency (EC50 0.4 μM) than taurine (EC50 116 μM) in activating native GABAARs, though both showed similar efficacy. The findings suggest GABAARs as plausible targets for taurine's potential benefits in health and lifespan extension and HT's effects in dementia and autoimmune diseases.
population_specificity: Murine cerebellar granule cells in brain slices and mouse brain homogenates.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to evaluate the effectiveness of pour-on fluralaner (2.5 mg/kg) in controlling Rhipicephalus microplus infestations in cattle and pastures in a tropical climate region.
results_summary: The study found that fluralaner treatments significantly reduced tick counts in cattle and pasture larvae compared to the control group, maintaining infestations close to zero for most of the study. Strategic retreatment protocols also reduced the number of applications needed, lowering costs and resistance pressure.
population_specificity: Taurine cattle in a tropical region with high tick infestation rates.
effective_dosage: 2.5 mg/kg pour-on fluralaner, applied every 42 days (T01) or as needed based on visual evaluation (T02).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine could mitigate oxidative stress and apoptosis in pancreatic β-cells of obese rats induced by a high-fat-high-glucose diet.
results_summary: Taurine supplementation significantly reduced oxidative stress markers, improved antioxidant capacity, and decreased apoptosis-related protein expression in the pancreas of obese rats. It also enhanced the activity of key signaling proteins (Nrf2, HO-1, KEAP-1) involved in cellular defense mechanisms.
population_specificity: Male Sprague-Dawley rats fed a high-fat-high-glucose diet.

study_goal: The researchers aimed to investigate the role of taurine metabolism in hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) progression, immune regulation, and its potential as a biomarker for prognosis and immunotherapy response.
results_summary: The study identified two HCC subtypes with distinct taurine metabolic profiles, linked to different genomic and immune characteristics, and developed a risk model that effectively predicted prognosis, immune cell infiltration, and immunotherapy response. The model was validated across multiple datasets and showed robust performance.
population_specificity: Patients with hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC).

study_goal: The researchers aimed to determine whether taurine supplementation during platelet storage improves hemostatic function under flow conditions and its association with metabolic pathways.
